Stifel Maintains Buy Rating on $PUMP, Raises PT to $20 from $7

Analyst comments: "We are reiterating our Buy and SHARPLY increasing our PT on PUMP to $20 from $7 based on our new sum-of-the-parts analysis detailed below. Our new target price reflects its substantial expansion plans for its Power business, including: 1) expectations to have 220 MW contracted by year-end 2025; 2) receiving delivery of 360 MW of power assets on order by early 2027; 3) ordering additional capacity to have 750 MW delivered by year-end 2028; and 4) the financial flexibility of a $350 million lease financing facility. Importantly, energy is a key bottleneck in the scaling of high-performance compute infrastructure, and hyperscalers appear willing to pay a premium for low-latency and highly reliable power infrastructure. Access to power is trumping the cost of power, and this is likely to persist, fueling demand for power assets like PUMP has on order."

Analyst: Stephen Gengaro

Needham Reiterates Buy Rating on $CVNA, PT $500

Analyst comments: "We continue to see Carvana as the best large cap growth story in our coverage with a visible, lengthy growth runway against conservative near term unit guidance vs recent results, with CVNA's consistent execution and long term guidance showing the power of the model and increasing separation from peers reporting more volatile results. We believe CVNA deserves multiple expansion as a long term compounder, similar to other clear-cut leaders in large TAMs such as streaming or food delivery. Our $500 price target is 35x our '27E adj EBITDA, or 25x our '30E adj EBITDA discounted back, and underwritten by CVNA achieving their 3M retail unit goal at 13% margins in 2033."

Analyst: Chris Pierce

Shareholders received 1 $SOLS share for every 4 $HON shares.

Canaccord Genuity Maintains Buy Rating on $TMDX, Raises PT to $147 from $142

Analyst comments: "TMDX delivered revenue in line with CGe, but slightly short of consensus, which we think will drive the stock down (and present an interesting buying opportunity) despite the solid overall quarter and guidance increase. TMDX delivered $143.8M in revenue vs. $144.1M CGe/$144.6M consensus. The quarter was essentially what we expected, as the overall Q3 transplant marketâ€™s seasonality (that management repeatedly communicated) impacted TMDX.

Given the expectation for a seasonally slow and relatively in-line quarter, we believe our thesis is intact and believe any dip in the stock price creates a buying opportunity for longer-term investors, especially considering the pipeline of growth drivers. We note that these drivers are not baked fully into our future expectations and include the Heart and Lung clinical trials integrating new devices and/or solutions in the US, implementation of NOP and logistics OUS, and US OCS Kidney â€“ all of which will occur over the next few years. We are keeping our forward estimates relatively unchanged and are reiterating our BUY rating. We are raising our PT to $147 from $142 as the comp group multiple increased."

Analyst: Jason Mills

$META $NVDA

The Meta 12% sell off feels weird for this one reason: 

How is the street giving Nvidia a $5T valuation on the backs of increased capex but at the same time punishing Meta for increasing capex?

I donâ€™t really get it. There are only a handful of companies that can buy $NVDA GPUs at the scale that the Mag 7 can. Meta is one of those companies.

Jensenâ€™s â€œ$500B in 5 quartersâ€ statement two days ago is largely fueled by companies like Meta that need to continue spending. $GOOGL and $MSFT also increased their capex guidance. 

So if the argument is $META is down because of being aggressive on capex for 2026, why is Nvidia holding $5T? They both should be symbiotic with each other: one providing the otherâ€™s revenue today while the other providing the otherâ€™s future AI ROI tomorrow. 

The tax charge is a nothing burger. Companies have to pay their taxes. Revenue growth was 26%â€¦every other core metric is up including ad impressions (14%) and price per ad (10%). 

So the street is upset that they are going to spend more? 

Now, the $25B bond raise this morning I think is the actual issue as investors are concerned that the company is continuing to fuel its capex financing via debtâ€¦which signals to me investors are more scared about no AI ROI. Thatâ€™s a fair concernâ€¦just not something that can be the biggest concern if the company supplying the chips for all that ROI is hitting ATHs but the customer buying it is getting punished for it.

I bought a little at $659â€¦2026 estimates looking like $META is now in the low 20sâ€¦will do more DD but not fully sold on actually establishing a position like I am on $AMZN (have been adding there aggressively over the past month) but a bit confused why the street is that upset about capex.

Silver is a better investment than Gold Long-TermğŸ§µ

Silver is so much more important and versatile metal than gold. Hence it is manipulated to the max, while everyone is praising Gold. More than half of silver supply or heading to 70% are going to industrial applications when Gold is 12% or less. Gold pathetic main case is jewelry. 

Silver:

Electronics: Silver is used in electrical contacts, switches, circuit boards, and conductors in nearly every electronic device, from smartphones and computers to household appliances.

Solar energy: In the photovoltaic industry, silver paste is applied to silicon wafers in solar panels to capture and transport electricity from sunlight.

Automotive: As vehicle electrification accelerates, the demand for silver in electric cars is growing. It is used in electrical connections, switch contacts, and engine bearings.

Medical: Silver is widely used in medical equipment, including coatings for breathing tubes and catheters, because of its antimicrobial properties that help fight infections.

Brazing and soldering: Silver-based alloys are used to join metal parts in applications from plumbing and refrigeration to aerospace and automotive engineering.

Not Financial Advice!
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/PVXEprmoHKylYGSPDcSDqnuz-x2s5saLe6NhrCIW2G8/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G4hnQp7WsAELkS2.png

$MSTR | Michael Saylorâ€™s Strategy Returns to Profitability on Bitcoin Gains

Strategy Inc., co-founded by Michael Saylor, returned to profitability in Q3, reporting net income of $2.8 billion, or $8.42 per share, compared with a loss of $340 million a year ago. 

Gains were driven by the rising value of its ~$69 billion Bitcoin holdings. Legacy software revenue rose 11% to $128.7 million, above analyst estimates. 

The company is exploring credit securities internationally, though demand for preferred stock remains tepid, slowing recent Bitcoin purchases. 

Strategyâ€™s guidance assumes a year-end 2025 Bitcoin price of $150,000.

$AMZN CEO ON RECENT LAYOFFS ANNOUNCEMNT:

The recent 14,000 job cuts were driven by culture, not financial and not even really AI driven, not not right now at least.

When you grow as fast as we did, you add layers and complexity that can slow you down. Sometimes that weakens ownership among the people actually doing the work and making day-to-day decisions.
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/u8T3nu4lZz_kwInkzAjZs2QcGdzd78DolRncagbGnMY/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G4ihodta8AEJGSM.jpg

[30/10/2025 23:55] Evan â€¢ TweetShift
[Tweeted](https://twitter.com/StockMKTNewz/status/1984016283306786943)

{Embed}
Evan (@StockMKTNewz) âœ§
https://twitter.com/StockMKTNewz/status/1984016283306786943
Amazon $AMZN CEO Andy Jassy just said when asked about Amazon's recent corporate layoffs:

"The announcement that we made a few days ago was not really financially driven. And it's not even really AI driven, not right now at least.

It really. It's culture. And if you grow as fast as we did for several years, the size of businesses, the number of people, the number of locations, the types of businesses you're in, you end up with a lot more people than what you had before, and you end up with a lot more layers. 

And when that happens, sometimes without realizing it, you can weaken the ownership of the people that you have who are doing the actual work. And who own most of the two way door decisions, the ones that should be made quickly and right at the front line. And it can lead to slowing you down. And as a leadership team, 

we are committed to operating like the world's largest startup. And that means removing layers and means increasing the amount of ownership that people have. And it means inventing and moving quickly. 

I don't know if there's ever been a time in the history of Amazon or maybe business in general with the technology transformation happening right now, where it's important to be lean. It's important to be flat, and it's important to move fast. And that's what we're going to do."
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/hyg1N_rG_akgEdkRdgCMjMlm3wRBGNxWkG4B03FbS9Y/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G4ikQahW8AARuyv.jpg

Jefferies on $RDDT (Buy, PT $300): 'Scary Good Growth'

Oppenheimer (Outperform; PT $290) â€“ Jason Helfstein
"Increasing target to $290 (from $245) as AWS 3Q revenue growth accelerated to +20% y/y vs. +17% in 2Q and is â€œgaining momentum.â€ Added 3.8 GW in the past 12 months, on track to double by 2027 (4x 2022 levels), with >1 GW coming online in 4Q. Kansas City Fed President Jeff Schmid was the only voting Fed member who voted for the FOMC to NOT cut rates this week

Fed President Schmid just relased a full statement as to his reasoning ... here is the full thing

Title - Dissent Statement by Jeff Schmid

"At this weekâ€™s FOMC meeting I dissented against lowering the target range for the federal funds rate by 25 basis points. My preference would have been to leave the target range unchanged.

By my assessment, the labor market is largely in balance, the economy shows continued momentum, and inflation remains too high. I view the stance of policy as only modestly restrictive. In this context, I judged it appropriate to maintain the policy rate at this weekâ€™s meeting.

Talking to contacts in the Kansas City Fedâ€™s district, I hear widespread concern over continued cost increases and inflation. Rising healthcare costs and insurance premiums are top of mind. In the data, inflation is spreading across categories, both goods and services.[1] Inflation has been running above the Fedâ€™s 2 percent objective for more than four years. As I have said before, I take small comfort in most measures of inflation expectations having not moved up. I view inflation expectations not as an input into Fedâ€™s decisions, but as the outcome of the policy decisions that the Fed makes.

As it is, I see the stance of policy as being only modestly restrictive. Financial market conditions appear to be easy across many metrics. Equity markets are near record highs, corporate bond spreads are very narrow, and high-yield bond issuance is high. None of this suggests that financial conditions are particularly tight or that the stance of policy is restrictive. Likewise, the economy is showing continued momentum. Consumption remains solid, and data for July and August suggest an acceleration through the summer.

Fixed capital investment, an interest sensitive component of growth, has shown some of the strongest increases. The contribution of software spending to GDP growth was the largest on record in the second quarter. And the contribution of investment in information technology to GDP growth in the first quarter was the highest on record with the exception of the first quarter of 2000.

With inflation still too high, monetary policy should lean against demand growth to allow the space for supply to expand and relieve price pressures in the economy.[2] With the dual mandate, Congress has directed the Federal Reserve to manage the trade-offs that arise from the economy-wide constraint that ties inflation to unemployment. Constraints lead to difficult decisions over how to balance competing objectives.

In certain circumstances the Fedâ€™s actions might have disproportionate effects on the two sides of the mandate. Now, for example, I do not think a 25-basis point reduction in the policy rate will do much to address stresses in the labor market that more likely than not arise from structural changes in technology and demographics. However, a cut could have longer-lasting effects on inflation if the Fedâ€™s commitment to its 2 percent inflation objective comes into question. In the end, inflation is the Federal Reserveâ€™s responsibility and within its control, and as I balance the mandateâ€”and the effectiveness of the Fedâ€™s actions in meeting that mandateâ€”my preference was to hold the policy rate steady at this weekâ€™s meeting."
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/7TCyoLQAlx0Wd5SiRMD0WHyeAZ-2cbwHDrATE1kKa5I/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G4luWLqWkAAT2oM.jpg

- "Samsung Electronics is building an AI factory with over 50,000 GPUs to accelerate its AI, semiconductor and digital transformation roadmap."

[31/10/2025 15:34] Palantir â€¢ TweetShift
[Tweeted](https://twitter.com/PalantirTech/status/1984252433283826098)

{Embed}
Palantir (@PalantirTech)
https://twitter.com/PalantirTech/status/1984252433283826098
Jonathan Webb, The Nuclear Company

America built over 100 nuclear reactors between 1960 and 1990. Weâ€™ve built just two since then.

Nuclear construction didn't just slow. It nearly died. The nation that first split the atom and put men on the moon somehow forgot how to pour concrete and weld steel at scale. Projects that should have taken five years stretched to fifteen. Budgets exploded from billions to tens of billions. The belief that we could build anything, anywhere, at any speed, the faith that defined American industry, evaporated.

We built The Nuclear Company to reverse this decline. Weâ€™re building an AI-powered deployment platform with technology-enabled systems that will allow our frontline teams to deliver Americaâ€™s next hundred reactors. The result will be low-cost, resilient, plentiful energy. And weâ€™re doing it by empowering the people who build them.

Consider what passes for normal in nuclear construction today. At the Vogtle plant in Georgia, the two reactors built over the last 30 years, more than 10,000 people worked at peak plant construction. Those workers often sat idle. Waiting on parts and materials. Waiting on engineering changes. Waiting on documentation. Just waiting. When documents did arrive (sometimes by wagons or wheelbarrows), the volumes of paperwork lacked specifics. Metal joints misaligned went undetected for weeks, forcing costly and lengthy rework. Workers knew problems were mounting. They could feel it, but they lacked the tools to see patterns fast enough to intervene. One told me: "We knew things were going wrong. We just couldn't see it fast enough to stop it." Our frontline workers are brilliant, but the tools theyâ€™ve had can't keep pace.

Weâ€™re building AI-enabled software that allows workers to command the build, not just survive it. Weâ€™re building it for the foreman on site at 4am, not just executives in boardrooms. AI agents trained on tens of thousands of pages of project documents identify problems in hours instead of months. Drones scan construction sites and catch misalignments within a millimeter, alerting workers through earpieces: "Please check that weld." That's giving American workers capabilities they've never had before.

This isn't automation replacing workers. It's augmentation elevating them. Kids with high school diplomas, people with two-year degrees. AI will help bring out their irreplaceable talents. 

We run our company from Middle America. Not New York City or San Francisco. As we build these facilities, weâ€™ll create some of the highest-paying construction jobs in the country and generate tax revenue for communities that need it most. Not for a few years, but for a century.

What we need is to make sure that our teammates can do their jobs. That's why we're giving them the tools they deserve, so building America's energy future doesn't break the people building it.
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/ePqiU2JkbFianC51SxLJ7HJ4VgPYOSaFOo1u2D2Liuo/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G4l6RYiXEAAwWKR.jpg

The ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ White House just released this fact sheet titled

"President Donald J. Trump Strikes Deal on Economic and Trade Relations with China ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡³"

Here's what the White House says is going to hapen

CHIN**ESE ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡³ A**CTIO**NS:

- Ch**ina will suspend the global implementation of the expansive new export controls on rare earths and related measures that it announced on October 9, 2025.
- China will issue general licenses valid for exports of rare earths, gallium, germanium, antimony, and graphite for the benefit of U.S. end users and their suppliers around the world. The general license means the de facto removal of controls China imposed in April 2025 and October 2022.
- China will take significant measures to end the flow of fentanyl to the United States. Specifically, China will stop the shipment of certain designated chemicals to North America and strictly control exports of certain other chemicals to all destinations in the world.
- China will suspend all of the retaliatory tariffs that it has announced since March 4, 2025.Â  This includes tariffs on a vast swath of U.S. agricultural products: chicken, wheat, corn, cotton, sorghum, soybeans, pork, beef, aquatic products, fruits, vegetables, and dairy products.
- China will suspend or remove all of the retaliatory non-tariff countermeasures taken against the United States since March 4, 2025, including Chinaâ€™s listing of certain American companies on its end user and unreliable entity lists.
- China will purchase at least 12 million metric tons (MMT) of U.S. soybeans during the last two months of 2025 and also purchase at least 25 MMT of U.S. soybeans in each of 2026, 2027, and 2028.Â  Additionally, China will resume purchases of U.S.Â sorghum and hardwood logs.
- China will take appropriate measures to ensure the resumption of trade from Nexperiaâ€™s facilities in China, allowing production of critical legacy chips to flow to the rest of the world.
- China will remove measures it took in retaliation for the U.S.â€™s announcement of a Section 301 investigation on Chinaâ€™s Targeting the Maritime, Logistics, and Shipbuilding Sectors for Dominance, and remove sanctions imposed on various shipping entities.
- China will further extend the expiration of its market-based tariff exclusion process for imports from the United States and exclusions will remain valid until December 31, 2026.
- China will terminate its various investigations targeting U.S. companies in the semiconductor supply chain, including its antitrust, anti-monopoly, and anti-dumping Â investigations.

AMERIC**AN ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ ACT**IONS**:

- The **United States will lower the tariffs on Chinese imports imposed to curb fentanyl flows by removing 10 percentage points of the cumulative rate, effective November 10, 2025, and will maintain its suspension of heightened reciprocal tariffs on Chinese imports until November 10, 2026.Â  (The current 10% reciprocal tariff will remain in effect during this suspension period.)
- The United States will further extend the expiration of certain Section 301 tariff exclusions, currently due to expire on November 29, 2025, until November 10, 2026.
- The United States will suspend for one year, starting on November 10, 2025, the implementation of the interim final rule titled Expansion of End-User Controls to Cover Affiliates of Certain Listed Entities.
- The United States will suspend for one year, starting on November 10, 2025, implementation of the responsive actions taken pursuant to the Section 301 investigation on Chinaâ€™s Targeting the Maritime, Logistics, and Shipbuilding Sectors for Dominance.Â  In the meantime, the United States will negotiate with China pursuant to Section 301 while continuing its historic cooperation with the Republic of Korea and Japan on revitalizing American shipbuilding.
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/D8jLBhZxWsTFy83HZqbgnBOugXmaYWEYF0Dg4ELWpgE/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G4tqSQTWkAAR_4k.jpg

I have this partially-formed hypothesis that artist backlash against generative AI crystalized largely in response to text-driven user interfaces.

The art world has come to accept tools like Photoshop (and earlier, photography itself) that still share the aesthetics of traditional art creation.  If MidJourney, ChatGPT, DALLÂ·E, etc had interfaces along the lines of Nvidia Canvas from 2020 (pictured below), it would look enough like existing tools that critique would look purist and elitist.

Art via command line, on the other hand, looks sufficiently Other that you can easily berate the users as Not Artists.  "You just typed a few words, you aren't an artist!" has a better ring than "Your drawing skills rely on Photoshop somewhat more than mine, you aren't an artist!"
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/8I9AX-_TFSfAPbzgrvrmV4_OUCDsC6DnFK88NEgV0_0/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G4t3Kq3bQAMm5XA.jpg

The next two deepdives are out!

These are on $GRAB and $NBIS.

The $GRAB deepdive is a refined version of a thesis I wrote up a few months ago that many people may have already read.

Nebius $NBIS is a name that has done exceptionally well for retail investors and is up 3x YTD. 

Given the AI revolution, the datacenter space has become integral and it seems like Nebius will play a very important role in this sector. After doing the deepdive, I do believe the company has a moat due to it's full stack, vertically integrated advantage and it is becoming very clear why people are choosing this name as their core datacenter exposure over the many other plays that are out there.

While the stock has already performed and it is understandable if investors feel they missed it (like myself), I tried to see the broader tailwinds for the business and if the $30B company could one day become a $100B company. 

Will be working on the next 2 deepdives for November (please leave any comments for tickers you'd like to see) along with some more deepdives into big tech earnings, the state of the bifurcated economy, where we are in the macro, and more!

Piper Sandler Upgrades $ROKU to Overweight from Neutral, Raises PT to $135 from $88

Analyst comments: "Roku 3Q results were unremarkable relative to our expectations. But commentary on the call suggests 1) strong underlying fundamentals in Platform across Ads and SSD. We now have more confidence in the Platform revenue glidepath into 2026 and take our revenue growth forecast to ~14.5% (from prior 12%), a starting point we think that could land in the high teens by year-end '26. Additionally, 2) ROKU was GAAP Op Income positive this quarter, well ahead of promised profitability for 2026. Finally, 3) like a 'grown up' company, ROKU began executing on its capital return program this past quarter repurchasing $50MM in stock of an initial $400MM plan."

Analyst: Thomas Champion

UBS Upgrades $CSCO to Buy from Neutral, Raises PT to $88 from $74

Analyst comments: "We upgrade Cisco to Buy based on a multi-year growth cycle driven by AI infrastructure demand, a large-scale Campus refresh cycle, and momentum in Security.

Key Drivers:

1. AI Infrastructure Demand Surging: a. Cisco secured over $2B in AI orders in FY25, nearly all from hyperscalers, with two-thirds for full systems running Silicon One and the rest optics/optical. b. Enterprise and Sovereign demand is now ramping, with Enterprise orders approaching $1B, up sharply from a couple hundred million dollars in the most recent quarter, positioning Cisco for sustained AI-fueled growth in FY26 and FY27.

2. Campus Refresh Cycle Accelerating: a. Ciscoâ€™s installed base includes tens of billions of dollars in aging Cat 4K/6K gear (5â€“15 years old). b. Upgrades to AI-enabled Smart Switches are expected to drive Campus growth from 5% in FY26 to approximately 7% in FY27.

3. Security Portfolio Reboot Gaining Traction: a. Next-gen products like Hypershield are growing over 20%, and Splunk integration is gaining traction."

Analyst: David Vogt

B. Riley Downgrades $RGTI to Neutral from Buy, Raises PT to $42 from $35

Analyst comments: "We like September's $11.5M in deals, which expand the commercial horizon as the path from 100- to 1,000-qubit systems from YE25 to 2030 gets going. Consensus 3Q25 estimates seem makeable, though we do not expect a 4Q25 guide per norms, and caution that delayed US government funding authorizations lend sales risk. Operating cash burn of approximately ($19M) per quarter seems manageable with $572M in cash. After popping 190% YTD to lift the market cap to $14.3Bâ€”which discounts 52% of the 2030 to 2035 TAMâ€”and with a significant percentage of long-term commercial success already priced in, we move to the sidelines with RGTI shares but with ongoing technology and commercial engagement attention."

Analyst: Craig Ellis

Aletheia Capital Initiates Coverage on $AMKR with Buy Rating, PT $62

Analyst comments: "We initiate coverage of Amkor with a BUY rating and a TP of $62, based on an SOTP (18x implied FY27E PER). Amkor, a leading U.S.-based OSAT provider, is well-positioned to benefit from two major secular tailwinds: the surging demand for CoWoS packaging and the America Manufacturing initiative. We expect Amkor to expand its existing overflow Hopper GPU packaging business with NVDA by capturing first-source CoWoS opportunities, including GB10, Vera and B30, as well as winning Broadcomâ€™s TPU V6 & V7 ASIC slots in 2026. In addition, Amkor could add new slots such as Spectrum-X, CPX, Tomahawk, etc. Amkor is constructing a $7 billion advanced packaging facility in Arizona, scheduled to begin operation in 2028. We believe this site has attracted strategic investment from key customers, reinforcing its long-term growth visibility and U.S. supply chain localization. We forecast Amkorâ€™s CoWoS sales to grow 2.5x in FY26E and a further 50% in FY27E, resulting in EPS growing at a 65% CAGR from FY25Eâ€“27E."

Analyst: Warren Lau

Xanadu Quantum Technologies to go public via a merger with SPAC, Crane Harbor Acquisition Corp. $CHAC, valuing the combined company at $3.6 billion, according to Bloomberg.

The deal includes $500 million in gross proceeds and a $275 million PIPE backed by investors such as AMD, BMO, CIBC, MMCAP Ventures, Planet First Partners, and Polar Asset Management.

Toronto-based Xanadu, founded in 2016, builds photonic quantum computers that operate at room temperature, avoiding the costly cryogenic cooling used by rivals. 

The stock will trade on both Nasdaq and the Toronto Stock Exchange once approved.

$PLTR

Palantir earnings today after the bell ğŸ¥¶

This will be my 18th quarter covering the company and things have changed dramatically from 4 years ago.

Street is expecting $0.17 of EPS and $1.09B of revenue. 

I believe Palantir will beat both of these numbers and grow revenues 50%+ this quarter.

Now, the stock has made a move to ATHs before earnings, so Iâ€™m not sure how good the beat will need to be for the street. 

As always, Palantir is a company that I genuinely care more about the actual company fundamentals more than the stock as the company is up 25x from the lows of 2022. I also plan to hold the name for a very long time so seeing consistent growth is the most important for me.

A strong topline beat, guidance raise for 2025, increased operating margins, and overall customer count will be important.

Ultimately, I believe that if the foundation model companies are getting higher valuations, then the company that is:

- actually profitable

- showing business usecases via AI in the enterprise

- and the single most important enterprise stack according to Jensenâ€¦

likely deserves to be one of the premier names in AI. 

No other company is growing as fast or with the types of margins that Palantir is growing with.

Excited to cover another quarter for the company that changed my life!

The U.S. housing market has seized up. 

Only 28 out of every 1,000 U.S. homes have changed hands in 2025, the lowest turnover rate in at least 30 years.

The problem isnâ€™t that people stopped wanting to move. Itâ€™s that millions are locked into pandemic-era mortgages around 3%, while new loans cost about 6.2%. Trading homes means adding hundreds more to a monthly payment.

Most owners are staying put, and that choice is rippling through the economy. Fewer moves mean weaker construction demand, slower job growth, and less consumer spending. 

The housing market is calcifying.
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/uv1IZpAznzRGlOA9hCvCXLYU2EPYNF-izWjYJ1RYyYc/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G42qESfbQAAJzRm.png

The U.S. Treasury cut its Q4 borrowing estimate to $569B, down $21B from Julyâ€™s forecast, mainly due to a higher starting cash balance. It now expects to end December with $850B in cash.

For Q1 2026, Treasury projects $578B in borrowing, also targeting an $850B cash balance.

In Q3, Treasury borrowed $1.06T, about $50B more than projected, driven by higher cash reserves and lower net cash flows. Further details will come with the Quarterly Refunding announcement on Nov. 5.

Sareptaâ€™s $SRPT ESSENCE confirmatory trial for Amondys 45 and Vyondys 53 FAILED to reach statistical significance, though the company said data showed â€œencouraging trendsâ€ favoring treatment over placebo.

Sarepta blamed the COVID-19 pandemic for data disruptions and said excluding impacted participants shows a clinically meaningful 30% reduction in disease progression over two years. The therapies maintained a favorable safety profile, and Sarepta will meet with the FDA to seek full approval based on ESSENCE plus multi-year real-world evidence.

Q3 revenue came in at $370M (down from $467M YoY), with $238.5M from PMO therapies and $131.5M from Elevidys. Sarepta also said it refinanced 2027 notes, achieved positive cash flow, and expects to finalize Elevidys labeling discussions with FDA soon.

Starbucks $SBUX is forming a joint venture with Boyu Capital to operate its China retail business, selling a 60% stake valued at about $4B (cash-free, debt-free) while retaining 40%.

The deal values Starbucks China at over $13B, factoring in the sale, its retained stake, and long-term licensing income. The venture will continue running 8,000 stores in China and aims to expand to 20,000 locations over time.

Starbucks CEO Brian Niccol said the partnership combines Starbucksâ€™ global brand with Boyuâ€™s local expertise to accelerate growth â€œinto smaller cities and new regions.â€

When there is no comp to a high quality business, that will often mean massive upside at an inflection point. 

I'm addicted to those no comp high quality businesses!

The problem is far too many are unwilling to study a business enough to own it before the inflection point. It is much easier to buy after it accelerated growth for quarters and years. 

That is not exactly superior return, it is called average return. 

With that said, nothing is wrong with being average. Most will have a nice retirement investing consistently w/ average return or just DCA into SP500

NFA

BofA Raises $HIMS PT to $32 from $28 - Underperform

Analyst comments: "HIMS reported a mixed quarter with revenue and EBITDA exceeding Street and BofA estimates, while total subscribers came in below expectations. The Sexual Health business is driving the weakness in the core, and HIMS expects that to continue in the first half of 2026. It is difficult to assess how much of the weak performance in Sexual Health is due to the transition from episodic to daily subscriptions, but 40% subscriber growth excluding this business was better than expected.

Incremental subscribers were weak this quarter and investments are rising â€” both trends likely to continue for the next few quarters. We acknowledge that HIMS is investing for growth and believe these investments can help differentiate HIMS over time. We see downside risk to 2026 consensus revenue estimates and lower our 2026 EBITDA estimates, leading us to reiterate our Underperform rating.

We roll our valuation framework from 2025 to 2026 and maintain our ~22x multiple (2025 multiple increasing from 22x to 25x), with our price objective increasing to $32 from $28. The higher implied multiple reflects incremental confidence in HIMSâ€™ strategy to verticalize the supply chain and invest in new verticals."

Analyst: Allen Lutz

Getty Images $GETY won a UK court case against Stability AI, with judges ruling that the companyâ€™s Stable Diffusion model infringed both trademark and copyright laws.

The court found that Stability AI used Gettyâ€™s copyrighted photos to train its model and that its outputs unlawfully included Gettyâ€™s watermark. Responsibility was placed directly on the model provider, not individual users.

Getty said it plans to use this ruling to strengthen its ongoing U.S. lawsuit and called for clearer global rules requiring AI developers to disclose training data sources.

[04/11/2025 14:02] amit â€¢ TweetShift

{Embed}
amit (@amitisinvesting) âœ§

$PLTR

Palantir put up one of the most exceptional quarters I have seen from any company, ever. 

To grow topline at 63% while growing operating margins to 51% and net income margins to 40% is a masterclass in efficient growth that I don't think the stock market has ever witnessed. 

The company has obviously put their foot in the ground and showed the market how AI is not only a tailwind for their business, but in the words of Alex Karp, "we own the market where value creation matters."

If we are talking about AI that is leading to transformational impact in the enterprise or on the battlefield, then the:

204 deals closed, 2.76B in TCV, 77% US Rev growth, 45% customer count growth, 114% on a Rule of 40 score shows that this is Palantir's market and they are absolutely dominating in it, even with less than only 1000 customers. 

Having said that, the stock did make a large move before earnings so the market taking it down after those results will lead people to believe it doesn't matter. 

Not much can be said for someone who gets upset that a stock which is already up 150%+ YTD goes down on earnings but for those that actual investors in Palantir and want to continue to see the business fundamental improve at the rapid scale that they are, this was the best quarter in the company's history.
TweetShift

$PLTR | ğğšğ¥ğšğ§ğ­ğ¢ğ« (PLTR): BofA raises ğğ“ ğ­ğ¨ $ğŸğŸ“ğŸ“ (from $215), maintains ğğ®ğ² â€” cites ğğ¢ğŸğŸğğ«ğğ§ğ­ğ¢ğšğ­ğğ ğ€ğˆ ğ ğ¨-ğ­ğ¨-ğ¦ğšğ«ğ¤ğğ­

https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/nHaSt66n8oHQbZk1shao_agT4bkKkvmi4J5yRPJQkxs/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G46M6tebQAQJsMN.png

[04/11/2025 14:05] amit â€¢ TweetShift
[Tweeted](https://twitter.com/amitisinvesting/status/1985679690447622260)

{Embed}
amit (@amitisinvesting) âœ§
https://twitter.com/amitisinvesting/status/1985679690447622260
$GRAB

GRAB Q3 2025 EARNINGS: 

- $873M revenue, +22% YoY 
- On-Demand GMV $5.8B, +24% YoY 
- Profit: $17M
- Adj. EBITDA: $136M, +51% YoY
- Adj. FCF (TTM): $283M
- 886M in loans, +56% YoY
- 48M monthly transacting users, +14% YoY

The company raised EBITDA guidance to $500M, up from $480M. 

This was an incredible earnings by Grab which continued to reinforce the bull case around their network effect leading to increased momentum around the most important parts of their business.

My core takeaways:

- Financial services is growing at a rapid pace and on track for 1B loans dispersed by EOY with a break even target for the entire segment by H2 2026. Management continues to grow this part of the business rapidly due to their ecosystem effect around being able to effectively underwrite the loans given all proprietary data they have on users which makes it seem like this growth will continue into 2026. 

- GrabUnlimited users hit an ATH, growing 14% YoY. This was very important to see given this is the largest subscription platform in all of SEA and also highlights the company's 6M YoY user growth. AT 48M MTUs, they are only about 7% of the region's population. As more users join, more topline growth can be expected going into 2026.

- Tourism is coming back and Anthony Tan spoke about how partnerships with various governments are creating strong incentives for Grab to play a pivotal role in the ecosystem around tourism in the entire region. Tan stressed that the company is NOT seeing issues with demand (in fact they had more demand than supply when it came to their drivers in Q3) and mgmt made sure for investors to understand their business is cyclical, they have a variety of tools at their fingers to really be able to effectively continue sustained growth. 

- Finally, new products are working. When Grab held their first product event earlier this year, they showcased a variety of new products that aimed to increase user engagement at scale. Grabâ€™s new products like Saver Deliveries, Group Orders, and GrabMore are driving both user growth and deeper engagement. Cross-selling between Food and Mart services has led to 1.8x higher order frequency among multi-service users, showing stronger loyalty and higher lifetime value.

The number one question for me as a shareholder is what exactly they plan to do with their cash. They have $5.3B of net liquidity and either they are going to use that to scale financial services going into 2026 or they are going to acquire, but this is still the question I am curious about as 30% of the market cap in cash provides a cushion to investors but also should be used to continue funding growth.

Overall, I thought this was an exceptional quarter which is laying the framework for the company to continue growth over the coming years. Yes, the stock price may not be reflecting that at the moment (it doesn't help as the broader market is down) but I don't see the red flags or reason for the market to take it down in this quarter.

For those wanting a compounder that is relatively cheap for the value of a brand dominating an entire region, Grab continued to show their strength in this quarter.
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/wbV921LsPVV43dzamKKMYsGWtRzMjPXyxor4oL0WOtU/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G46NJzVWMAAtTIt.jpg
TweetShift â€¢ ğŸ“·1

When I hear shorts attacking what I believe is clearly the most important software company in America, It's crazy motivating & I'll tell you why they are getting screwed by Palantir

These people they could pick on any company in the world, but they have to pick on the one that actually helps people, that actually has made money for the average person, that is actually supporting our warfighters.

The median age for first-time homebuyers in the U.S. has reached 40, the highest on record, as rising prices and mortgage rates continue to delay homeownership. 

First-time buyers now make up just 21% of all home purchases, the lowest share since 1981, while the median existing home price stands at $415,200, up more than 50% since 2019.

The National Association of Realtors estimates that losing a decade of homeownership could cost roughly $150,000 in equity on a typical starter home. Repeat buyers are older, with a median age of 62, and often wealthier, paying cash or making larger down payments. 

Source: NAR
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/pN-kg3d_jA7YAdB4TdLx3gl_TAOdT3_pTABUG9WEU_I/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G47EBXEbQAQl0lZ.png

Raymond James Reiterates Market Perform Rating on $PLTR

Analyst comments: "Palantir delivered a standout 3Q25 driven by record U.S. Commercial momentum, accelerating U.S. Government execution, and a sharp inflection in deal activity. Revenue of $1.181B (+63% year-over-year) topped consensus by roughly 10%, with adjusted operating income of $601M (51% margin), adjusted free cash flow of $540M (46% margin), and a Rule-of-40 score of 114%.

U.S. Commercial revenue surged 121% year-over-year and 29% quarter-over-quarter to $397M â€” its highest quarterly contribution yet â€” while U.S. Government revenue climbed 52% year-over-year to $486M, supported by the continued ramp of large defense programs. Momentum appears sustainable, as Palantir closed a record number of large deals (204 at $1M+, 91 at $5M+, and 53 at $10M+) and posted its largest-ever U.S. Commercial total contract value at $1.31B (+342% year-over-year), underscoring expanding enterprise adoption of AIP.

Management raised guidance across revenue, margins, and free cash flow (FY25 revenue $4.396â€“4.400B; adjusted operating income $2.15â€“2.155B; adjusted FCF $1.9â€“2.1B). That said, Palantir was priced to perfection, and valuation still sits at 85x 2026 sales (versus 7x in 2023), despite trading lower on the print. With this valuation in tow, we maintain our Market Perform rating, opting to admire what is looking like a historic race to the top of the market-cap echelon of public companies â€” although we wonder what could cause a pullback to make valuation and expectations more digestible."

Analyst: Brian Gesuale

Raymond James on $PLTR (Mkt. perform): 'was priced to perfection and valuation still sits at 85x 2026 sales'

"Palantir delivered a standout 3Q25 driven by record U.S. Commercial momentum, accelerating U.S. Government execution, and a sharp inflection in deal activity. Revenue of $1.181B (+63% year-over-year) topped consensus by roughly 10%, with adjusted operating income of $601M (51% margin), adjusted free cash flow of $540M (46% margin), and a Rule-of-40 score of 114%.

U.S. Commercial revenue surged 121% year-over-year and 29% quarter-over-quarter to $397M â€” its highest quarterly contribution yet â€” while U.S. Government revenue climbed 52% year-over-year to $486M, supported by the continued ramp of large defense programs. Momentum appears sustainable, as Palantir closed a record number of large deals (204 at $1M+, 91 at $5M+, and 53 at $10M+) and posted its largest-ever U.S. Commercial total contract value at $1.31B (+342% year-over-year), underscoring expanding enterprise adoption of AIP.

Management raised guidance across revenue, margins, and free cash flow (FY25 revenue $4.396â€“4.400B; adjusted operating income $2.15â€“2.155B; adjusted FCF $1.9â€“2.1B). That said, Palantir was priced to perfection, and valuation still sits at 85x 2026 sales (versus 7x in 2023), despite trading lower on the print. With this valuation in tow, we maintain our Market Perform rating, opting to admire what is looking like a historic race to the top of the market-cap echelon of public companies â€” although we wonder what could cause a pullback to make valuation and expectations more digestible."

Analyst: Brian Gesuale

A Stanford study published in NMI found that major AI chatbots, including ChatGPT, often fail to distinguish b/w factual knowledge & personal beliefs. 

Researchers tested 24 large language models across 13,000 questions and found they were 34% less likely to identify false beliefs than true ones.

The U.S. Department of Energy announced $625 million in funding to renew its 5 National Quantum Information Science Research Centers, first launched under the 2018 National Quantum Initiative Act.

The next phase focuses on advancing quantum computing, networking, and sensing capabilities while strengthening U.S. leadership in quantum technology.

Among the renewed centers is Fermilabâ€™s Superconducting Quantum Materials & Systems Center (SQMS), where Rigetti Computing $RGTI serves as a core partner, alongside Northwestern, Caltech, Ames Lab, JPL, NIST, and INFN.

The center will focus on scaling superconducting quantum devices and developing quantum data center technologies.
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/-5P08PoRIqCy1lpL9dlXzoMXHIalvdMI7if_3kXROeM/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G48RFeFaQAApWVl.jpg

$GOOGL and Epic Games have settled their long-running antitrust dispute.

Terms were not fully disclosed, but both companies told the court the agreement will support more developer choice and lower fees on Android.

The settlement keeps the court-ordered rule allowing developers to offer payments outside Google Play with commission caps of 9% or 20%. It also replaces the earlier requirement for Google to share its full app catalog with a system for â€œregistered app storesâ€ that will receive equal treatment on Android devices.

The settlement also resolves related litigation between Epic and Samsung. Both sides now await final court approval.
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/S8yIh65dlZ4Q1zL2F5KBuXYBiALeDy0iu3B8E_YhUf8/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G4-oVvKawAAzxcI.jpg

Roth/MKM Downgrades $UUUU to Sell from Neutral, Raises PT to $11.50 from $7.25

Analyst comments: "In July 2025, we downgraded Energy Fuels to Neutral as we believed the companyâ€™s market value was in line with the fundamental value of its assets. At that time, shares traded at $6.51. Since then, enthusiasm around rare earth and uranium-focused companies drove Energy Fuelsâ€™ share price to a high of $27.33 in mid-October, despite no material changes to its underlying assets, no direct government investments, and continued losses. While we remained Neutral during the run-up due to strong market momentum and a lack of near-term catalysts for a correction, we now see that momentum fading. With multiple financial studies expected before year-end 2025 or early 2026 and sector sentiment likely peaking, we believe it is time for investors to take profits if they have not already done so."

Analyst: Joe Reagor

UBS Raises $AMD PT to $300 from $265 - Buy

Analyst comments: "With AMD hosting its first Analyst Day since before ChatGPT next week, there was little new in earnings to shift the broader debate, and that proved true. Given the rally in shares ahead of the report, a short-term pullback is possible, but we would not look to time it given likely positive updates at the Analyst Day. AMD is expected to outline a path toward $15 to $20 in EPS later this decade, with AWS potentially serving as an additional catalyst, possibly at re:Invent in early December.

As for results, AMD delivered a revenue beat and guided above expectations, though some AI GPU shipments appeared pulled forward from calendar Q4 into Q3, possibly due to Oracle. Importantly, AMD dispelled concerns that its AI GPU business might face a first-half 2026 slowdown while reaffirming that GPU sales will be weighted toward the second half due to the OpenAI ramp. While investors remain focused on AI GPU momentum, we note that agentic AI is also driving a strong refresh of traditional compute infrastructure, which we estimate will account for over 35% of AMDâ€™s EPS in 2026, positioning the company as the key beneficiary given Intelâ€™s lack of a competitive roadmap."

Analyst: Timothy Acuri

Raymond James Lowers $SMCI PT to $50 from $53 - Outperform

Analyst comments: "Supermicro negatively preannounced results on October 23, calling for sales of ~$5B vs. its prior forecast for $6â€“7B. Margin weakness will undoubtedly remain the focal point, and shares were trading down ~10% after hours. The weak F2Q26 margin guidance reflects some unique foundational expenses related to capacity expansion, as Supermicro prepares to scale its operations ahead of expected revenue growth. Management remains confident that it is laying the groundwork for eventual margin expansion through higher volumes and improvements in manufacturing efficiencies. Despite this, the timeline for improvement remains vague and investors likely remain weary. Our price target goes to $50, reflecting the intermediate-term margin headwinds."

Analyst: Simon Leopold

Evercore ISI Lowers $MTCH PT to $35 from $38 - In Line

Analyst comments: "Match group reported in-line Q3 revenue, a solid 9% Q3 EBITDA beat (excluding a litigation settlement charge), and offered mixed Q4 guidance (revenue midpt 2% below the Street, EBITDA midpt 3% above). Per management, MTCH has now completed the 'reset' phase of its turnaround plan (changing the culture and accelerating operating and product cadence) and early results from product tests and investments have been encouraging. 

The company is currently evaluating 2026 capital deployment priorities and plans a spring 'relaunch' of Tinder, following 'Project Aurora,' a large-scale test of a reimagined Tinder experience now underway in Australia. 

Management also increased their estimate of 2026 iOS IAP savings to $90MM from $65MM prior (with line of sight to an additional $10â€“15MM of Android-related savings on a recent Play Store policy change), though it remains unclear if some of the savings will be redeployed into product or marketing. 

While we have layered the full $90MM of savings into our revised 2026 Adj. EBITDA estimate of $1.38B, we also see a fairly wide range of potential Adj. EBITDA outcomes for 2026 depending on managementâ€™s still pending strategy and capital allocation moves."

RBC Capital Lowers $PINS PT to $38 from $45 - Outperform

Analyst comments: "PINS had a disappointing Q3 print. Tariff-related weakness showed up for the first time in our digital ads universe and will reinforce PINS' lack of customer diversity for the bears and higher macro sensitivity. Lowering ests and price target moves to $38.

Key positives: 1) Further solid evidence of product improvement with Performance+ retail advertisers seeing 24% higher conversion and 12% higher monthly spending growth rates, 2) Engagement growth continues with 16% user growth and 40% impression growth which was encouraging though largely coming from ARPU-dilutive geos.

Key negatives: 1) Pullbacks from some large advertisers owed to home furnishing-related tariffs drove the Q4 guide down with it being unclear if Amazon was a part of that weakness, and could call the 3p retail media auction density thesis into question (see our intra-qtr ad load which showed Amazon down meaningfully). While tariffs was a known risk, intra-qtr communications on tariffs may drive some outsized reaction here. 2) Anecdotes of product-related improvements are encouraging but selected examples of outsized growth continuing to not foot with overall reported numbers remains a challenge. 3) The expected 2H margin expansion < 1H is playing out but the implied Q4 leverage appears minimal which won't instill confidence in next year's expansion. 4) Management stuck to its long-term targets where mid/high teens on revenue could be looked at as less achievable & with capitulation still to come. We stick with PINS at Outperform given our views that a comfortable LT double digit grower with margin expansion should trade higher than an implied single digit EBITDA multiple on '27 numbers - though we acknowledge the product cycle story may be on ice for the time being."

Analyst: Brad Erickson

Goldman Sachs Lowers $CAVA PT to $68 from $74 - Neutral

Analyst comments: "CAVA reported 3Q25 SSSG of +1.9% vs. GS/VA of +2.5%/+2.6%, with management calling out lower frequency among younger consumers, while unit growth tracked in-line with our estimates at 415 stores at quarter end. Lower G&A (with lower performance-based incentive compensation) helped to mostly offset higher-than-expected restaurant expenses, which flowed through to adjusted EPS of $0.14, in-line with our estimates. Bottom-line: We continue to believe in CAVA's long-term growth potential amid the company's focus on delivering an exceptional guest experience through operational enhancements (technology, equipment, new Assistant General Manager role), culinary innovation, and a re-imagined CAVA Rewards program. That said, we think this is balanced by near-term, industry-wide macro pressures that we expect to weigh on traffic, including the intense promotional environment as well as challenges faced by the younger consumer cohort (aged 25 to 35) driving more cautious spending. We also acknowledge a "honeymoon effect" from outsized 2024/2025 openings, which we expect to continue in 2026. As a result, we remain Neutral rated on CAVA with a new $68, 12m TP."

Analyst: Christine Cho

$FTNT LAUNCHES NEW AI DATA CENTER SECURITY STACK

Fortinet rolled out a Secure AI Data Center solution built around a new FortiGate 3800G firewall designed for high-density GPU data centers. 

The hardware supports 400GbE, up to ~800 Gbps firewall throughput, ~210 Gbps IPsec, and ~200M concurrent sessions, aiming to handle AI cluster traffic loads.

The broader framework adds protections for LLM environments like prompt injection safeguards, data leakage controls, and quantum-safe encryption options. 

Fortinet says the architecture also lowers power use vs traditional setups.

Raymond James Raises $KTOS PT to $97 from $80 - Strong Buy 

Analyst comments: "The company stacked business wins in 3Q that increase our confidence that Kratos can double its revenue base over the next three years or so. Kratosâ€™ 3Q25 results again exceeded expectations, highlighted by double-digit organic growth, healthy B2B > 1.0x, and continued healthy margins. Management raised its fullyear revenue forecast, reiterated its EBITDA target, and provided an 2026-27 framework that remains conservative in our view given the companyâ€™s record backlog, expanding international opportunities, and accelerating mix shift from development to production. Our model remains perched above the 2026 and 2027 guide. The stock is trading off due to another 2H-weighted year reflecting cost pressure from legacy fixed-price target drone contracts and heavier bid-and-proposal spending. Likewise, while the full-year top-line guide went higher, EBITDA remained flat and cash burn is a bit high â€” all signaling another investment year. After shares have more than doubled since June (vs. S&P 500 up 15%), the stock is taking a breather as shares were priced for perfection, the chart consolidates in a healthy manner, and investors book some profits. We view this pullback as an opportunity to pick up shares on a business with strong multi-year growth visibility via long term contracts almost perfectly aligned to national security priorities including unmanned systems, hypersonics, engines, air defense, and space."

Analyst: Brian Gesuale

JPMorgan and $NVDA are already using it to test scalable quantum algorithms.

There's a capacity issue in the US high-protein yogurt market

Danone says demand for high-protein yogurt in the US is running so hot that they literally canâ€™t produce enough. Half of their US yogurt lineup is Greek and mostly high-protein, and sales have surged even more with the rise of GLP-1 weight-loss drugs.

Because of this, Danone has been slower to launch new yogurt products and expand distribution. The company is now adding capacity at several US facilities, including Minster, Ohio, but supply will likely stay tight until that comes online.
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/vg0EIbFxXNxzMCPq28DBWVXbsMHjv9mO6ZlIb2-pZjQ/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G5BDgyobIAIbEKw.png

There's a capacity issue in the US high-protein yogurt market

Danone says demand for high-protein yogurt in the US is running so hot that they literally canâ€™t produce enough. 

Because of that, theyâ€™ve been slower rolling out new products and even had to limit distribution on some SKUs since plants are already maxed.

The company is now adding capacity at several US facilities, including Minster, Ohio, but supply will likely stay tight until that comes online.

Note: Half of their US yogurt lineup is Greek and mostly high-protein, and sales have surged even more with the rise of GLP-1 weight-loss drugs.

Perplexity will be accessible directly in Chat, offering conversational, source-linked answers alongside Snapâ€™s existing My AI.

Perplexity will pay Snap $400M over a year (cash + equity) as the integration rolls out globally. 

Snap says this is its first large-scale integration of an external AI partner and expects revenue contribution to begin in 2026.

https://twitter.com/wallstengine/status/1986358579176308857
Chipmaker Nexperia says it has halted supply to its China manufacturing unit after the local team refused to make required payments and did not follow corporate governance directives. 

The company has warned customers it cannot guarantee the quality or authenticity of chips produced at the China facility since October 13.

Nexperia also accused the unit of misusing company seals and opening unauthorized bank accounts to divert funds.

The company said facilities outside China are operating normally. The situation follows weeks of operational disruption after the Dutch government temporarily took control of Nexperia and China blocked exports of some products. 

Nexperia says it expects to resolve the governance dispute and remains committed to its operations in China.
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/LTfAW7eTshxBhDEIuXxoCJe5jwebs_JkBclCoV9gmpM/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G5D2kKDbIAULaZw.png

Piper Sandler Downgrades $ELF to Neutral from Overweight, Lowers PT to $100 from $150

Analyst comments: "While strong momentum at rhode is continuing (40% growth expected in FY26, strength across categories), 3-4% sales growth implied for core ELF in FY26 is disappointing and not deserving of a premium multiple, in our view, considering resilience of the category (improved to +2% vs. -1% in F1Q26), easing comparisons, comments about strength in innovation and struggling competitive set in mass. Profitability is also resetting, with EBITDA margin guided for a 200+ bps decline, with lack of clarity on further investment cycle that may be necessary at rhode. Stock is under pressure after hours but is still pricey at 32x FY26 guide (and 30x our FY27 est.)--while rhode sales could see upside this year (Sephora UK launches next week), in absence of the core business rebounding beyond MSD, we think the multiple could re-rate lower."

Analyst: Anna Andreeva

BofA Raises $QCOM PT to $215 from $200 - Buy

Analyst comments: "The strong results are supported by handset strength in China, attributed to timing of the Chinese holiday and product launches, as well as solid performance in non-handsets and long-term opportunities in data centers. However, the intermediate term outlook is somewhat challenged, with some of the handset strength being cyclical and potentially short-lived. The smartphones semiconductors, an ex-growth industry, still represents 71% of QCT revenues, having multiple aspects of peak activity. Chinese vendors account for ~68% of handset QCT revenues; there are signs of self-development at Xiaomi; Samsung share expected to decline in F2Q from 100% to 75%; and Apple contract ending in about one year. As IoT, Auto, and Data Centers ramp, the stock multiple should expand, but handset concentration is the key transitory risk."

Analyst: Tal Liani

GXO offers such efficiencies in the form of using â€œautomated sortationâ€ and â€œintelligent roboticsâ€ to complete order fulfillment and reverse logistics for corporate supply chains."

Morgan Stanley Initiates Coverage on $GLXY with Overweight Rating, PT $42

Analyst comments: "We view Galaxy Digital as a compelling combination of 1) a nascent AI data center developer with a clear path to monetizing one of the largest single-campus HPC data centers under development and 2) a blockchain-enabled investment bank. Initiate OW, $36-48 base case range ($42 midpoint PT).

Our $36-48 base case range implies 15-54% upside, driven by scenario analysis. Our base case is based on an EV/Adjusted Gross Profit ratio that applies a 7.7x multiple to our CY27 Digital Assets adj. gross profit range of $317-519mm. The midpoint of our base case range contemplates a 90% probability (80-95% range) of an incremental 800 MW approval, and a 35% chance of approval (25-45% range) of the remaining 1.9 GW Galaxy has under study thereafter."

Analyst: James Faucette

Reuters reports $GOOGL is planning a major AI data center on Christmas Island (Australia), following its cloud deal with the Australian Department of Defence. Google is in talks to lease land near the island airport and secure power through a local mining partner.

The island is seen as strategically important for monitoring activity in the Indian Ocean. Analysts say a local AI data center could support forward command-and-control and unmanned systems, especially if satellite links are disrupted.

Google has also applied to build a subsea cable connecting Christmas Island to Darwin. The project is still undergoing local review, with the community weighing economic benefits vs. increased defense presence.
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/yXMcCMksUwY4ES56uCwVsL-E-5MHTomyxCq8IukbsZY/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G5EAijRboAALtza.png

William Blair says Costcoâ€™s $COST October comps were strong, and what stands out is that Costco intentionally reduced both the depth and breadth of seasonal items like toys and holiday decor that lean on China sourcing, and shifted more space to apparel and home goods that stay relevant past the holidays. 

Store checks show noticeably lighter Halloween and Christmas displays than prior years, yet conversion held.

Analysts say this speaks to Costcoâ€™s merchandising discipline and ability to pivot assortment without losing momentum. Blair views the result as a positive read for holiday demand at the higher-income level.

The broader consumer setup remains split: higher-income households are still spending, while lower-income trends are weakening. Blair expects a more bifurcated holiday season with clear winners and losers. Costcoâ€™s value positioning, limited SKU model, and higher-income member mix place it firmly in the â€œwinnerâ€ category.
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/ccdTAICfcAgd-SHE5J1VfC0kCrLN8nHV_Ob0hh3tGO0/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G5EBh90bIAMPQc6.jpg

BofA on $APP (Buy, PT $860): 'Solid Q3 print, but few details of eCommerce ramp available'

"Q3 revenues were +12% Q/Q, ahead of BofA/Street/Guide of 10%/7%/6%. The print exceeded the median of investors we spoke with, although 1/3 had much higher expectations." 

"Management pointed to incremental gaming model improvements as the driver of the beat and noted that eCommerce remained small. We estimated Q3 eCommerce Net Revenue of $140mn. That eCommerce would not move the needle was well known pre-print. EBITDA margin of 81% was in line with Street/BofA/Guide. 4Q25 revenue guidance of $1.6bn at the high end was below BofA and investors we spoke with pre-print." 

"Management indicated that forecasting eCommerce net revenue in Q4 was difficult because of the influx of new advertisers since its self-serve (referral) launch on October 1. Nonetheless, the guide incorporates favorable mobile game advertiser seasonality, a contribution from international audiences, and continued model self-learning." 

"Newly onboarded advertiser spent less, in aggregate than the first eCommerce cohort; we model $43mn (vs. $83mn Dec â€™24). We now assume that by December â€˜25, 2400 advertisers will be live, although spend per advertiser will likely be $65K."

Analyst: Omar Dessouky

Charles Schwab is acquiring Forge Global $FRGE for about $660M in cash, paying $45 per share. 

The deal is expected to close in the first half of 2026, pending regulatory and shareholder approval.

Forge runs a private market trading platform where investors have transacted over $17B in private company shares. Schwab says the acquisition will help expand access to private market investing for its retail and advisor clients, adding liquidity and data transparency to an area that has historically been limited to institutions.

Forgeâ€™s major shareholders, including Motive Capital and Deutsche BÃ¶rse, have agreed to support the deal.

$PENN Entertainment and ESPN are ending their ESPN BET partnership early, effective Dec. 1, 2025. The deal originally ran 10 years with $150M annual payments, but the companies agreed to wind it down after the platform didnâ€™t reach targeted market share.

Microchip $MCHP introduced an AI, MCP Server that lets engineers pull specs, datasheets, pricing and lead-time info through AI tools and chat interfaces. 

It connects directly to LLMs and copilots using streamable MCP standards, returning structured JSON responses for design and sourcing workflows. 

The server is free to use and is aimed at speeding component selection and development decisions.

SkyWater Technology $SKYT and QuamCore are teaming up on superconducting chip tech for large-scale quantum computing. 

SkyWater will provide U.S.-based superconducting manufacturing, while QuamCore brings its Single Flux Quantum control architecture designed to operate at ~10 millikelvin.
 
The SFQ control approach can cut cabling by up to 1,000x and significantly reduce power versus CMOS, which is key for scaling qubit systems. 

The partnership targets test chip demonstrations over the next 12â€“18 months as part of QuamCoreâ€™s roadmap toward million-qubit systems.
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/9140Dkk9Z10_ARiX77l7XyEcnMcOBanJgoHQS0WalQ8/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G5EiTeJaYAAeTm6.png

Skyworks $SWKS introduced new programmable clock chips for 5G/6G wireless and hyperscale data centers. 

The families use Skyworksâ€™ BAW technology with DSPLL to cut jitter for high-speed SerDes and support IEEE 1588 sync for massive MIMO radios. They target 800G+ optical links and next-gen radio units, eliminating external crystal references and reducing component count. Production and eval boards available now.

BofA Securities Raises $SNAP PT to $10.00 from $9.50 - Neutral

Analyst comments: "We are encouraged by Snapâ€™s steady progress in diversifying its revenue base and significant new revenue contribution from Perplexity deal. However, advertising still represents over 80% of total revenue, and growth rates reflect intensifying competition and sluggish usage trends. Positives could include cost management upside in 2026, while risk is a pressure on users from cost optimization initiatives and new social media age verification safeguards. At an after-hours price of $8.37, stock is valued at 10x our 2027E EBITDA & 16x FCF, not including SBC expense. Reiterate Neutral."

Analyst: Justin Post

Microsoft $MSFT is now moving ahead on developing superintelligence after its new agreement with OpenAI cleared the restrictions that previously prevented it from pursuing AGI-level systems on its own. 

Mustafa Suleyman announced that he will lead a new MAI Superintelligence Team, focused on building AI that can outperform humans in tasks related to materials science, medicine, clean energy and personal AI agents.

Suleyman said the goal is what he calls humanist superintelligence, meaning powerful systems designed to advance practical breakthroughs, not just push model size.

TRUMP ADMIN ANNOUNCES GLP-1 PRICE DEALS

The White House struck agreements with Eli Lilly $LLY and Novo Nordisk $NVO to cut prices on GLP-1 drugs. Direct-to-consumer injections will start around $350 and trend down to ~$250, with tablets expected at $149 if approved. 

Medicare and Medicaid patients with qualifying conditions will pay $245/month, and $50 co-pays for diabetes versions. Lilly also gets 3 years of tariff relief.
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/QxcpkGEiuPATxy62qnVyYrgTz5cbgs7y-9NDWtoJ2Cg/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G5FnfNdbIAEsAUQ.png

"Next growth vectors - Prediction markets & Crypto exchange! Quarter after quarter, Robinhood management raises the bar and tells us why the stock deserves its valuation. 

How do you model a company that adds couple of $100Mn revenue businesses every year? Consider these metrics - Life-time high quarterly revenue (100% YoY, 29% Seq.), $333bn platform assets (119% YoY, 19% Seq.) and lifetime high 26.8mn users and 3.9mn Gold users (77% YoY).

This quarter apart from record trading revenues, Robinhood presented two more $100mn revenue businesses that just 6 months back, would not form a material part of any street model - Prediction markets and Bitstamp crypto exchange."

Stifel Upgrades $PENN to Buy from Hold, Raises PT to $21 from $19

Analyst comments: "We are upgrading PENN to Buy from Hold, and raising our target price to $21. Our value-unlock thesis outlined here was predicated on an ESPN Bet exit and pivot to iCasino-led digital strategy, which we got today ahead of schedule. B&M fundamentals remain stable since inflecting Q2, proving out resilience yet again amidst softening demand elsewhere in GL&L, with encouraging initial trends at Joliet & line-of-sight to annualization of new competitive opening headwinds. Pushback on our upgrade call will undoubtably be 'what's the catalyst to re-rate?' with PENN surprisingly underperforming on the announcement, though we see room for shares to grind steadily into the $20s with an attractive NTM catalyst path still left: 1) annualization of new competitive casino openings & resulting B&M inflection, 2) proof points of attractive return on project spend, 3) steady iCasino share ramp potentially accelerated by re-allocated financial/operational resources, and 4) Interactive asset monetization optionality."

Real-estate giant Blackstone is liquidating a major investment gone wrong:

A $1.8 billion wager on senior housing that has saddled the firm with more than $600 million in losses.

It is shaping up to be one of the New York firmâ€™s worst investments in recent years.

Blackstone has been quietly selling off its portfolio of about 9,000 senior-housing units across the U.S. through a series of one-off transactions, sometimes at losses of more than 70% compared with their purchase price

Overall, a Journal analysis of 39 of Blackstoneâ€™s senior-housing properties found that the firm paid more than $755 million for them. Between 2022 and 2025, the firm sold or is in contract to sell those properties for about $536 million, about 29% less than the purchase price.

(Source WSJ)
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/hPQozBYcrRF2znBCSADr-CwxgWRaKWoM2_D1S_NBXqY/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G5LpsiRWgAEBNal.png

CRISPR Therapeutics $CRSP reported positive Phase 1 results for CTX310, its gene-editing therapy targeting ANGPTL3 for severe lipid disorders. In the highest dose group, the single IV treatment cut ANGPTL3 levels by up to 89%, triglycerides by up to 84%, and LDL by up to 87%

The therapy was generally well tolerated with no treatment-related serious adverse events. The company plans to move into Phase 1b, focusing on severe hypertriglyceridemia and mixed dyslipidemia. Presented at the AHA Scientific Sessions and published in NEJM.

Visa $V and Mastercard $MA are nearing a settlement with merchants that aims to end a 20-year-old legal dispute by lowering fees stores pay and giving them more power to reject certain credit cards

Under terms being discussed, Visa and Mastercard would lower credit-card interchange fees, which are often between 2% and 2.5%, by an average of around 0.1% over several years

They would also loosen rules that require merchants that accept one of a networkâ€™s credit cards to accept all of them. For example, some stores might turn away rewards cards, which charge them higher fees and in recent years have become very popular with consumers

A deal could be announced soon and would require court approval to take effect

(Source WSJ)
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/pwJzcX-JPpT-AnAApK9L1GQ4zOe0K0_WUbioROUHz94/https/pbs.twimg.com/media/G5VMdcuWsAAulQO.png

ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ Senators have reportedly reached a deal to end the government shutdown

The Senate just passed the first step of a deal to end the U.S. government shutdown. The procedural vote cleared with exactly 60 yes votes after Sen. John Cornyn flew in late to cast the final one. 

The plan funds the government through January and guarantees a December vote on extending ACA subsidies. The shutdown wonâ€™t officially end until the House approves it and President Trump signs it

ğŸ“¢ ğ‰ğ”ğ’ğ“ ğˆğ: WISeKey and Columbus Acquisition execute merger for WISeSat spin-off - $WKEY $LAES $WHIN 

Under the agreement, WISeKey will receive 25 million shares in the new public company at $10 per share, representing $250 million in equity value. The transaction is expected to close in the first half of 2026, with WISeKey retaining majority ownership of the combined entity.

WISeSat operates a constellation of nanosatellites designed to provide secure Internet of Things connectivity. The company has launched 22 satellites with 14 currently operational as part of its Low Earth Orbit constellation. WISeSat plans to deploy 100 satellites by 2030 to serve industries including agriculture, logistics, defense, and environmental monitoring.

The satellites incorporate post-quantum cryptographic chips from SEALSQ Corp (NASDAQ: LAES), another WISeKey subsidiary, along with encryption and authentication systems. WISeSat plans to launch its next-generation post-quantum-secure satellite aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket from Vandenberg Space Force Base in November 2025.

WISeKey and SEALSQ are expected to invest at least $10 million in cash to WISeSat in connection with the business combination. The agreement allows WISeKey to distribute up to 10% of its received shares to its shareholders immediately after closing.

Deutsche Bank Upgrades $MP to Buy from Hold, Raises PT to $71 from $68

Analyst comments: "We believe MP now represents a buying opportunity for investors wanting to have exposure to the thematic of critical minerals and Rare Earth on the medium to long-term. MP is the only player in the West as a fully integrated Rare Earth company, which is also backed up by the US government. We have a clear growth path ahead with (i) an elevated pricing floor support from the government of $110/kg; (ii) volumes growth through heavy refining, magnet and recycling, placing MP in a strategic and unique position. We believe we could see further upside in numbers in the coming quarters, depending on refinery progress and whether a mine plan optimization could come into play at Mountain Pass, although we believe those would be medium- to long-term added opportunities."

Analyst: Corinne Blanchard

[10/11/2025 11:20] Wall St Engine â€¢ TweetShift
[Tweeted](https://twitter.com/wallstengine/status/1987812396325654965)

{Embed}
Wall St Engine (@wallstengine) âœ§
https://twitter.com/wallstengine/status/1987812396325654965
Morgan Stanley Downgrades $JD to Underweight from Equalweight, PT $28

Analyst comments: "JD had benefited the most (vs. other e-Commerce platforms like Alibaba and PDD) from trade-in policy since late August 2024 because its GMV/sales exposure to home appliances and electronics was the highest. However, the effects of trade-in policy are tapering and the benefits are turning into a high base from 3Q25. We expect JDR's revenue growth to slow down to 5.6% YoY in 4Q25 with potential YoY declines in home appliance and electronics sales. Looking into 2026, we expect JDR's revenue growth to slow further, to 4.4% YoY.

We expect the tapering trade-in effects and hence slower revenue growth to lead to less operating leverage for JD over the next 12 months. In addition, JD's incessant investments in new businesses are likely to drag down its long-term margins and ROE. We expect JD's non-GAAP net margin to decline to ~2.3-2.5% in 2025-30 and project structural deterioration in its ROE from 20.3% in 2024 to 12.6% in 2030."

Analyst: Eddy Wang

Raymond James Upgrades $VSAT to Outperform from Market Perform, PT $52

Analyst comments: "We upgrade VSAT to Outperform with a $52 price target after F2Q26 results. We believe, despite very strong stock performance over the past ~6 months (after a rough few years since our downgrade in 11/2022), there remains substantial sum-of-the-parts (SOTP) upside plus several catalysts. Investors are starting to recognize the significant value of the Defense & Advanced Technologies (DAT) business as VSATâ€™s strategic review for a possible spin-out continues, with comps trading in the 20s to 40s+ EV/EBITDA vs. Satellite businesses typically in the single digits, and a spin could better realize the valuation gap. Moreover, the very important Viasat-3 (VS-3) F2 and F3 launches are imminent, and while VSATâ€™s last couple of launches have had minor to major issues, we think the current valuation accounts for launch/in-service risk. These launch risks, along with SpaceX Starlink competition, uncertainty on the strategic review outcome and timing, and minor government shutdown risks, keep us from going to Strong Buy, but we think the risk/rewards are quite compelling."

Analyst: Richard Prentiss

Goldman Sachs Maintains Buy on $DKNG, Lowers PT to $54 from $59

Analyst comments: "Coming out of Draftkings Q3â€™25 earnings, we'd highlight a few themes: 1) while Q3 revenue of $1.14bn and Adj. EBITDA of $(126)m were both below GSe/Street and company guidance for the quarter on the back of customer-friendly sports outcomes in September, underlying growth was healthy with NFL handle up +13% and NBA handle up +19% year-over-year in the season to date; 2) the company signaled an upcoming push into prediction markets with DraftKings Predictions (including sports event contracts); 3) FY25 EBITDA guidance was lowered due to a combination of customer-friendly sports outcomes in September/October and prediction markets launch costs, with FY26 also now likely to be impacted by investments related to prediction markets and the new ESPN partnerships (with ROI on these buckets of spend still TBD); 4) core value drivers continued improving; and 5) enhanced capital returns as the company authorized a doubling of the share repurchase program. We maintain our Buy rating but lower our 12-month PT to $54 (from $59) as we adjust our forward estimates for this earnings report and management's updated forward commentary."

Analyst: Ben Miller

Marriott $MAR has ended its licensing agreement with Sonder $SOND after Sonder defaulted. Sonder properties are no longer part of Marriott Bonvoy or bookable through Marriott channels. Marriott says it will contact guests who booked through its site or app to help rework plans. With Sonder rooms removed, Marriott now expects about 4.5% net rooms growth in 2025, but says the rest of its financial outlook remains unchanged.

Needham on $DKNG (Buy, PT $52): The most important take away from earnings is Draftkings will be launching prediction markets with sports, implying they will effectively have a nationwide sports betting product. It would be better if this outcome happened through OSB regulation than prediction markets. 

But the baseline for our model is no additional state launches after MO, therefore we think our medium term EBITDA should be higher now with prediction markets than without it. There is a cost of this added TAM and we are taking down our adj. EBITDA estimates to ~ $1B for '26E, although assume this is a one-year investment cycle and leave our '27E estimates unchanged."

Applied Digital $APLD says its subsidiary APLD ComputeCo plans to raise $2.35B in senior secured notes (due 2030) in a private placement. 

Proceeds would fund construction of two new data centers (100MW + 150MW) at its 400MW Polaris Forge campus in North Dakota, repay existing SMBC debt, and set up reserve accounts. 

Notes will be secured by substantially all assets of the data center entities. Offer still subject to market conditions.
